results.headline: Disgraced Life Conjures Mysterious Forces

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Condemned

results.summary_short: “The Condemned,” directed by Roberto Busó-García, is billed as a psychological thriller inspired by either a drunken joke or a ghastly medical experiment.

results.headline: Darkness Descends on a Family

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Stoker

results.summary_short: The territory staked out in “Stoker” — a landscape of family secrets, sexual subtext and aristocratic entitlement — is at times reminiscent of a Henry James tale.

results.headline: Below the Surface, Demons Personal and Political

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Phantom

results.summary_short: In “Phantom,” a Soviet submarine captain dispatched on a final cold war mission confronts a handful of K.G.B. radicals intent on deploying the sub’s nuclear missile.

results.headline: Inner Child Comes Out to Rage

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Molly's Theory of Relativity

results.summary_short: The main characters in “Molly’s Theory of Relativity” — a father, his son and his daughter-in-law — are volatile, complicated people in touch with their inner children.

results.headline: Or Would You Rather Be a Fish?

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Leviathan

results.summary_short: Lucien Castaing-Taylor and Véréna Paravel’s “Leviathan,” set on a groundfish trawler out of New Bedford, Mass., emphasizes the brutality of fishing.

results.headline: A Mighty Beanstalk Grows a New Twist

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Jack The Giant Slayer

results.summary_short: “Jack the Giant Slayer” sticks with the familiar bedtime story, embellishing it with 3-D and other effects, noisy battles and an occasional wink at the material.

results.headline: Shtetls to Subdivisions: A Modern Jewish Journey

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hava Nagila (The Movie)

results.summary_short: “Hava Nagila (The Movie)” uses that song as a prism though which to tell a complicated story of cultural adaptation while providing a fresh look at a good chunk of modern Jewish history.

results.headline: A Family Not Quite on the Up and Up

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Genius on Hold

results.summary_short: Truth is stranger than fiction in “Genius on Hold,” in which an inventor works with bookies and his son becomes a thief.

results.headline: Science Anchors an Unsettled Life

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Future Weather

results.summary_short: In Jenny Deller’s “Future Weather,” a junior high student with a difficult home life finds solace in school, especially science.

results.headline: To the Ramparts for Mother Earth

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Fierce Green Fire

results.summary_short: “A Fierce Green Fire: The Battle for a Living Planet” chronicles the history of the environmental movement from a largely localized phenomenon to an international one.

results.headline: Terror in the Suburbs (and Job Market)

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dark Skies

results.summary_short: “Dark Skies,” directed by Scott Stewart, retools the haunted-house thriller for recessionary times.

results.headline: A Child-Eye’s View of Life in 1970s China

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 11 Flowers

results.summary_short: In “11 Flowers” the director Wang Xiaoshuai draws on boyhood memories, including an encounter with a murderer, for a story set near the end of the Cultural Revolution.

results.headline: A Deal With the Devil to Save a Beloved Son

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Snitch

results.summary_short: “Snitch” stars Dwayne Johnson as a company owner who enters the illegal-drug world to help reduce the sentence of his imprisoned son.

results.headline: It’s All About My Failed Romance

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Rubberneck

results.summary_short: “Rubberneck” and “Red Flag,” two wispy, downbeat movies, were written and directed by Alex Karpovsky, the actor who plays Ray the barrista on the HBO show “Girls.”

results.headline: It’s All About My Failed Romance

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Red Flag

results.summary_short: “Rubberneck” and “Red Flag,” two wispy, downbeat movies, were written and directed by Alex Karpovsky, the actor who plays Ray the barrista on the HBO show “Girls.”

results.headline: Bromance, Cricket and Sectarian Riots

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kai Po Che

results.summary_short: The Bollywood movie “Kai Po Che” sets a story of three friends against the backdrop of the 2002 massacres of Muslims by Hindus in northwestern India.

results.headline: You Can’t Escape the Past, and Other Truisms

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Inescapable

results.summary_short: “Inescapable,” directed by Ruba Nadda, takes the missing-daughter conceit of “Taken” and moves it to revolution-torn Syria.

results.headline: Survival of the Fittest, or Just of Coping Skills

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of One Life

results.summary_short: “One Life,” a nature documentary from the BBC, examines the survival skills of some of the planet’s most clever animals.

results.headline: In This House, Don’t Fixate on the Views

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Murder 3

results.summary_short: In the Bollywood thriller “Murder 3,” a photographer attracts women to his gorgeous estate, but then they tend to disappear.

results.headline: Nice Aliens, Evil Human

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Escape From Planet Earth

results.summary_short: In “Escape From Planet Earth,” space-traveling blue beings are lured to Earth by an evil general seeking to steal their technology.
